verses.verse: And all the kings of the earth sought the presence of Solomon to hear his wisdom, which God had put in his heart.
Each man brought his present: articles of silver and gold, garments, (1 Kin. 20:11) armor, spices, horses, and mules, at a set rate year by year.

Solomon (Deut. 17:16; 1 Kin. 4:26; 10:26; 2 Chr. 1:14; Is. 2:7) had four thousand stalls for horses and chariots, and twelve thousand horsemen whom he stationed in the chariot cities and with the king at Jerusalem.
(1 Kin. 4:21) So he reigned over all the kings (Gen. 15:18; Ps. 72:8) from the River to the land of the Philistines, as far as the border of Egypt.
(1 Kin. 10:27) The king made silver as common in Jerusalem as stones, and he made cedar trees (2 Chr. 1:15-17) as abundant as the sycamores which are in the lowland.
(1 Kin. 10:28; 2 Chr. 1:16) And they brought horses to Solomon from Egypt and from all lands.

Death of Solomon (1 Kin. 11:41) Now the rest of the acts of Solomon, first and last, are they not written in the book of Nathan the prophet, in the prophecy of (1 Kin. 11:29) Ahijah the Shilonite, and in the visions of (2 Chr. 12:15; 13:22) Iddo the seer concerning Jeroboam the son of Nebat?
(1 Kin. 4:21; 11:42, 43; 1 Chr. 29:28) Solomon reigned in Jerusalem over all Israel forty years.
Then Solomon rested with his fathers, and was buried in the City of David his father. And Rehoboam his son reigned in his place.
The Revolt Against Rehoboam And (1 Kin. 12:1-20) Rehoboam went to Shechem, for all Israel had gone to Shechem to make him king.
So it happened, when Jeroboam the son of Nebat heard it (he was in Egypt, (1 Kin. 11:40) where he had fled from the presence of King Solomon), that Jeroboam returned from Egypt.
Then they sent for him and called him. And Jeroboam and all Israel came and spoke to Rehoboam, saying,
“Your father made our yoke heavy; now therefore, lighten the burdensome service of your father and his heavy yoke which he put on us, and we will serve you.”
So he said to them, “Come back to me after three days.” And the people departed.
Then King Rehoboam consulted the elders who stood before his father Solomon while he still lived, saying, “How do you advise me to answer these people?”
And they spoke to him, saying, “If you are kind to these people, and please them, and speak good words to them, they will be your servants forever.”
(1 Kin. 12:8-11) But he rejected the advice which the elders had given him, and consulted the young men who had grown up with him, who stood before him.
And he said to them, “What advice do you give? How should we answer this people who have spoken to me, saying, ‘Lighten the yoke which your father put on us’?”

Then the young men who had grown up with him spoke to him, saying, “Thus you should speak to the people who have spoken to you, saying, ‘Your father made our yoke heavy, but you make it lighter on us’—thus you shall say to them: ‘My little finger shall be thicker than my father’s waist!
